body:
Hi @HYang1996, as said, adding this would be great. I'd approach it as follows: 
* do a bit more online research if it already exists, google searches, perhaps open an issue on statsmodels or even better, ask in their Googlemail list
* read about ETS in https://otexts.com/fpp3/expsmooth.html
* get the R version to run on the airline data set (or any other data set, but we've got the airline data set in sktime too) in RStudio or so
* start translating the version from fable into Python, inherit from BaseSktimeForecaster https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/67c56be8b1e838f2628df829946f795b7dba9aed/sktime/forecasting/base/_sktime.py#L21
* Check results against results obtained in R, perhaps even for certain methods/steps
Sorry didn't mean to un-assign you

issue.title: Draft PR for ets

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at
the extension guidelines: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs

Fixes #327 



#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.

Implements automatic ETS based on R version.



#### PR checklist for new estimators 

- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally. 
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.
- [ ] I've updated sktime's [estimator overview](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/ESTIMATOR_OVERVIEW.md) and I'm committed to maintain my contribution and provide bug fixes if necessary.
- [ ] I've added myself to the list of contributors


#### Any other comments?

This is a draft PR, the class is not completely finished.

issue.title: ETSModel with auto-fitting capability similar to R implementation

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at
the extension guidelines: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->

Fixes #327, replacing #350 .

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented. 
-->

Created a wrapper for statsmodels' latest implementation of ETSModel, and added an auto-fitting option which is similar to the implementation in R.

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one? 

<!--
If your contribution does add a new dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate
 companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum. 
-->


#### PR checklist for new estimators 
<!--
This is only relevant if you contribute a new estimator
 (classifiers, regressors, forecasters, etc
.). If so, please go through the checklist below. Otherwise please ignore check list.


-->

- [x] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally. 
- [x] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.
- [x] I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/master/CODEOWNERS) and I'm committed to maintain my algorithm.
- [x] I've added myself to the list of contributors
- [x] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.

#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.

Thanks for contributing!
-->

Simple tests have been performed to compare results from this forecaster against those from the statsmodels' version, and auto-fitting capability is tested against R implementation on the airline dataset.
